text:
On the outskirts of Kyiv,
civilians-turned-soldiers

stake a line of defense
around the capital.

They run maneuvers in
newly dug trenches.
Practice sharpshooting.
[gunshot]

And when training is done,
they return to base camp.

It’s a base replete
with mess hall …

… transport units
and barracks.

In urban warfare,
a shut down retail warehouse

like this one became
a defense post,

where the newly enlisted
learn to fight on the job.

The soldiers agreed to let
The Times film at their base,

but for security reasons,
ask that we not
disclose its location.

“The first time I hold this
thing, it was two weeks ago.

I was assigned to this
unit to, at this position,
to fight the tanks.

So we’ll blast over
the top of the tank,

where the armor is
the weakest point,

and fires through
the whole thing.

That could even ignite the
whole battle ammunition
that is inside the tank.

So it’s going to blow
up like a candle.

You know, we are
defending Kyiv.

It’s not that we are far
away from the capital,
so the stakes are high.”

In the battle for Kyiv,
Ukrainian anti-tank munitions

struck a Russian convoy
as it approached the city,

a punishing attack
filmed by the Azov Battalion.
It was a turning point.

As Russian forces
continued to lose ground

around the capital,
they stepped up

their aerial
assault, targeting
civilian infrastructure.

The largest attack to
date was a shopping mall

in northern Kyiv,
where at least eight people
were killed.

Russia claimed
the mall was being

used to store rockets
and mobile launchers,

a claim the Ukrainian
military denied.

The soldiers in this
repurposed store
know they could be targeted.

They bed down in a small
bunker-like office,
fortified by concrete.

By now, all of
these volunteers

know the stakes for
themselves and for Ukraine.

Everyone here seems
to be settling in,

ready to confront an enemy that
says it’s withdrawing for now,

but that could strike
again at any moment.
